qas.question: What is the name of a US government agency tasked with trying to stop improper use of antibiotics?

answers.text: US Interagency Task Force on Antimicrobial Resistance

qas.question: Which agencies control this task force?

answers.text: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH)

qas.question: When did the French start going after overuse of antibiotics?

plausible_answers.text: US Interagency Task Force on Antimicrobial Resistance

qas.question: What is the name of a US government agency tasked with trying to stop the FDA?

plausible_answers.text: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH)

qas.question: When did the French start going after children?

plausible_answers.text: The issues of misuse and overuse of antibiotics

qas.question: What has been adressed by an NGO campaign group?
What are organizations who are lobbying to other US agencies concerned with?

context: Several organizations concerned with <b7_0>antimicrobial resistance<b7_0/> are lobbying to eliminate the unnecessary use of antibiotics. <b6_0>The issues of misuse and overuse of antibiotics<b6_0/> have been addressed by the formation of the <a0_0><b3_0>US Interagency Task Force on Antimicrobial Resistance<b3_0/><a0_0/>. This task force aims to actively address antimicrobial resistance, and is coordinated by the <a1_0><b4_0>US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH)<b4_0/><a1_0/>, as well as other US agencies. An NGO campaign group is Keep Antibiotics Working. In France, an "Antibiotics are not automatic" government campaign started in <a2_0><b5_0>2002<b5_0/><a2_0/> and led to a marked reduction of unnecessary antibiotic prescriptions, especially in children.
